Not a 1 because I think it's awful, but more because I don't think tcgs should be listed as "boardgames". A boardgame should come with everything we need to put it on the table and play, and where the content is at our disposal to have access to the whole game. Or at least you can have the opportunity to collect everything from the game in an objective way.

But because of the way Magic has become, I don't consider it a game anymore. It is a lifestyle. And a very arbitrary one. I won't be able to compete with friends unless I invest in a specific way a lot of money. The base decks are so awful and boring that most people would simply put this game on sale if Magic were only these mediocre decks.

But more than that, Magic is a marketing business. I think it's a shame that so many teenagers are investing thousands of dollars, when they could have had a lot of better games for the same investment. And I think it's even more shameful that companies still promote this type of marketing. We should be passed that as consumers, but industries and influencers push us towards accepting it rather than criticizing it and getting over it.

All in all, it is not a game. It's a toxic investment. And it's an unequal one because it all depends on someone's income, available resources, and most of all, pure luck in a lottery system. I hope that as a gaming community, we'll stop falling for this and go to what a true game is supposed to be: fun with your friends and families, and a great and memorable experience with your closed ones.

Mtg is an absolute failure in terms of balance: some cards are clearly better than others, creating unending power creep as time goes on, and this flaw also allows Hasbro to intentionally leech off their loyal customers by creating more OP and stronger cards indefinitely, forcing their loyal customers to keep spending a ton in order to stay competitive.

Roughly speaking, 25% money (better cards/more options), 25% luck (lucky draws-topdecks), 25% deck building/netdecking skills, and finally 25% actual playing skills determines your overall strength in Magic (and of course, there is draft, which is just less card options and more luck involved). Magic clearly is a game that absolutely requires a player to constantly pay a high price tag if he wants to stay competitive.

Hardcore Magic fans love to point out how Magic is a game with endless possibilities, then I politely counter reply -while somewhat agreeing to their statement-, by pointing out how cards are overprinted (inflation; constant dependence of new influx of cards just in order to barely stay afloat; I mean, image if Hasbro stops printing new Standard sets: Magic would experience a slow death), and how the majority of Magic cards are not good enough to be usable (except in limited) in most constructed formats; a lot of what's considered as Magic's "endless possibilities" are far more artificially exaggerated (statistically) creating an illusion of much greater complexity than Magic is (I believe BGG's 3.3 Weight is about right; anyone who claims Magic has more strategy and depth than Chess or -god forbid- Go, is delusional; my point is, having a ton of useless and unviable cards does not make a game more complex, it's just more time-consuming in a very bad way) when you honestly think about it.

However, if you can overlook Magic's (personally, unforgivable) flaws, then actually it's a very fun and addictive game.

Lastly, Magic is also a very fun social/multiplayer game. The possible amount of customization of your decks is pretty incredible, too.

Well, my experience with MTG started when I was a kid in the mid 90s. Overall, it was an addicting game and my experiences were good for the most part. Fast forward to a couple of years ago where I decided to pick it up as a hobby again. Now that I'm smarter and less naive (and more aware of the great selection of independent games out there), I've found this game to be lacking.

First: Even after years of development, this game is still poorly balanced. Set after set, my jaw drops in disbelief that they could not possibly realize how broken their cards continue to be. This problem is so severe that we see that all tournament winning decks (and by extension many more competing decks) all revolve around a small number of cards. If broken enough, rare cards are easily more expensive than their new category of legendary or super rares. This level of ineptitude for a company that has the financial resources and experience that it does should be unacceptable by today's standards where many smaller independent company's have developed beautifully balanced games involving asymmetrical warfare (sorry I couldn't come up with a better term off the top of my head).

Second: This point regards the costs. Now, I don't have a problem with games costing money and I understand that collectible cards games are a fun way to put a lot of money (in smaller more acceptable increments) into a hobby. My point here regards the competence of Wizards of the Coast yet again. Put simply, the "pros" and more in-touch MTG players don't even bother with booster packs. To illustrate, pros playing the game online would sooner sell the booster packs to save up more money for buying specific cards in the market place. So, this game has such severe balancing issues and such a rigid hierarchy in the value of cards that the purchasing of booster packs, which is supposed to be the most typical way casual and most players collect these cards, is cost inefficient and left for the "suckers". Further one this point of costs, Wizards of the Coast even go against their own incentives to inflate the costs of cards. They still don't ban cards that were clear mistakes in their major tournament (cough lotus needs to die cough). They used to reprint older sets in boosters. I've seen them and bought them. They were a little more expensive, but I was okay with it and understood why.

Third: Finally, MTG is just an overrated game and is a drain on the gaming community as a whole. Like I've hinted at, I believe there is talent out there to design superior games than MTG. But there isn't a market for the collectable card game from a smaller company as it requires substantial distribution and widespread demand. Bot most kids who play MTG don't know about other options and once they burn out on MTG like some of the other 1 ratings you see here, they sure as heck don't want to move onto another collectible card. In conclusion, MTG needs to pass on to the next life. It's not that bad of a game, but the ineptitude of Wizards of the Coast and the fact that there's so much more potential out there is evidence enough that MTG detracts from rather than contributes to the gaming community.

As an afterword, this is all my opinion. Though, I do try to justify my opinion as much as possible. I hope this review contributes to a larger discussion (which should be had). Thanks for reading

I've been an MTG player intermittently for over 15 years now. If not for the commander format I would have stopped playing this trash heap of a game years ago. It's not that the design of the game is bad, and it can definitely have those really fun epic moments, but I'm not really interested in a pay-to-win style game where the development of cards and their interactions with the 20K unique cards that came before it is essentially left up to the player base to playtest and find "oh hey this is broken af" meanwhile it's allowed in play as MTG hasn't gone back to ban the broken cards they put out.

The real problem though is the pay-to-win side of this. For example, my buddy's EDH deck (Commander) has 6-8 land cards worth somewhere in the range of $2500. Now add in all the other cards he blew mad money on and he's at a $6-7k ~ deck now. He crushes anyone he plays with the deck, both in our game group and in the MTG tournaments held at game stores. He easily wins %95 of his games simply because he's spent more money on a deck than his opponents did. Multi-player, and especially, Commander as Multi-player; to a lesser degree, EDH as such

Magic is one of my favourite games of all time, but I feel compelled to rate EDH and multi-player in general separately from the main game. The reason is that at a fundamental level, adding more players (more specifically; more sides) to Magic makes the game play out very differently than the 1 on 1, or even one side vs. one side (i.e.: Two Headed Giant) and turns the game into something that I generally dislike in practice as the decision tree collapses down into politics the vast majority of the time, invalidating most of the other game considerations.

To understand why, you have to look at how Magic is constructed as a game. You have the fundamental skills of building a deck (sometimes with consideration for what the other players at your table / in your area are doing) as well as skillful play within the game itself.

At the multiplayer table, the game no longer directly rewards either of those skills and collapses into politics all too often as the person perceived as either being the most skilled, or who is thought to be piloting the most dangerous deck, or the person who currently seems most likely to win all become targeted and beaten back down into parity with the rest of the pack; until the next threat arises, and so on we go. What results is often a very long game where the winner is determined only in the last frame or two by a random draw or two that put them in position to win unexpectedly, or by a gaffe as someone finally fails to check the person to their left effectively.

Some of this is just because of table conventions (people often hate to beat on the player in last, but because of that they linger and the game just goes on and on and on) but also is just endemic to the way MtG seems to play out in this format. I've played it multi in numerous groups over the decades, and the dynamic always seems identical.

Also, a not insignificant issue for me is that in multi-player there's often just too much going on at the table to really keep effective track of everything that is happening. I don't like slowing the game down to read everything that is coming out, but sometimes if you don't do a bit of that people just win with a combo, so the game effectively forces everyone to spend a bunch of time trying to keep multiple other board states in mind, with EDH being particularly bad about this because everyone is playing a large deck of singletons and modern card complexity creep means that almost every card now has a paragraph of text to parse.

Some of the people I play with like the casual, politicky aspect of the game, but I've played enough of it over the years to know that this just isn't my jam, and I really try to avoid it as much as possible. The play in practice can hold my attention for maybe 30 minutes, but in practice any table with more than 3 usually makes for a game that is 60 minutes if it goes VERY fast, and usually is 2 to 3x as long as that depending on the decks, which is just way too long for what is actually happening in practice. The higher starting life total in EDH exacerbates the game length amongst "fair" decks, and also incentivizes combination wins to an irksome degree. In practice this means you have to spend yet more time insuring a combo isn't building, which means you need to pay even more attention to the other boards, which adds yet more time to the game...and on and on.

When we do play multi, I always lobby for Planechase with a shared, totally random Planar deck as a way to at least shake things up in an interesting way as it can unexpectedly cause the game to change in a way that helps keep it somewhat more interesting for me and the 4 rating I'm giving here is assuming that that is in play. Without it, we're probably at least at 3, and in some ways, a real 2, as I think the game (as an an actual game as opposed to an activity) is just poor with more than two sides.

On a slight aside, EDH as such is also not a great format for my tastes. The higher life totals makes deck construction very combo focused to be competitive and the nature of this format seems to collapse the truly reasonable deck construction options down a lot because of that super high starting life total. Normal constructed has some semblance of balance between rush, mid-range, and combination / big haymaker end game play, but in EDH rush just isn't that great because the life totals are so high, so the only real "rush" option is to try and make a quick combo. The remaining 2 deck types tend to favour the bigger end game, which is why this format has long been known for "Battle Cruiser" type decks, which is some of the most boring Magic play for my play preferences.

Most modern deck-vs-deck games either provide several fixed decks for players to choose from, or they give you a set of preconstructed decks that you have the option of customizing later. Magic is such a wide space, and decks are expensive (at least premade commander decks). Simply having "a deck" isn't good enough, because power level varies so broadly, and each deck needs tools to deal with anything you throw at it.

For example, every deck needs both tools for combat damage (creatures) and tools for removal (not creatures). Every deck needs flyers or creatures with reach (who can block flyers). Every deck needs draw power. Every deck needs... something.

On the one hand, you definitely need everything in these categories, which makes deckbuilding hard. And also, you might not draw the tools you need, because card draw in Magic is so hard.

But more importantly, the reason that the game has all these tools (flying, combat damage, removal...) is because the game isn't /about/ anything. There's no core mechanic -- something like an auction, or rock-paper-scissors, or word-association, or inductive logic. The extensive game elements are just papering over a dry mechanical framework.

Granted, the game was designed in 1993. I'm looking at a base engine that came from 1993 as if it was a modern game, which is probably not fair to Richard Garfield. I'm sure Netrunner is more interesting, because it has actual bluffs, actual mind games, and the resources are pulled out of the deck and into currency.

I'd have to drop other games, play competitively online, and likely get into a local testing group to really jump to the next level. I had a wife, friends who really didn't care about Magic, and a demanding job. I let the dream go, and gradually began spinning off my collection.

Magic taught me a lot in my time with it. I never thought that I could have gotten as far as I did, and it gave me a lot of confidence in my ability to learn and improve. The regimented method of always looking for holes in my game, and the ability to suppress my emotions to continue playing for my best shot to win has carried over into my life. I feel that I have become better at assessing my own performance, not just in games, but also in day to day life. I'm patient with my own mistakes (or at least, more than I used to be), and I am much better at hearing criticism than I used to be. All these things came from my time playing competitive Magic, along with countless other gifts and lessons I haven't listed here.

Magic is a deeply flawed game in many respects. There are countless barriers to entry, and there are very serious questions about the ethics of its business model. A rather messy, random game. There are two main ways to play the game, each with its own problems:

* "Limited", of which I played Draft. Each player spends c. £10 on brand new cards, which go round the table, players pick one card at a time. You can already see one problem there, although it's actually the cheaper way to play. The decks you build with the cards you pick will probably be fairly random, with few cards repeating in a deck. You will probably try to choose cards that work somewhat well together in a deck but fancy combos are out of the question. Some mechanics may be hard to take advantage of at all (I found the recently re-introduced snow lands rather useless).

* "Constructed", where players come with the decks they've built from their collections. This is where the proper game begins, this is what hardcore players spend their time and money on. The requirement on time and money is also what I personally object the most. On one hand, this is where you can really put your mind to work, as well the cards you collected through playing Limited games, and try to conjure up a perfectly synchronised deck to win all your games. On the other hand, you are going lose to someone who got their deck on the internet. It's not cheating, it's "metagame", and is a big part of MtG. If you want to beat them by playing an even stronger deck from the internet, you need to be prepared to spend a lot of dough on rare cards (and remember you typically need 4 copies).

OK, you're playing Limited or Constructed, doesn't matter. You've got yourself a deck you're happy with, you've got a clear strategy in your head, and an idea on how to counter your opponent's moves. You're ready to go. What you forget though is that you're still playing a card game, and you lose if you don't draw the cards you need. No lands? Too many lands? All you can do is watch how your opponent beats you.

I've gone back and forth on this game many times over the course of my life. I dislike the TCG business model, but in practice, history has borne out that there is no comparable alternative if you want a game with the variety, scope, ability to support a game store, and built-in community of a collectible game. LCGs seem great on the surface, but as time goes on, the barrier to entry grows, often encouraging you to spend full price on boxes that might only have one card you need. Magic decks can be expensive, but the price of building one viable competitive deck, while usually high, doesn't tend to increase drastically over time. LCGs also have too many SKUs for stores to reliably support all but the truly successful ones, of which there have been remarkably few, and none of which have been competitive games (much love to Netrunner and Null Signal, of course). Not to mention that limited formats like draft become a whole other beast in an LCG.

While the booster pack model is an uncomfortable proposition for a competitive game, it also undeniably allows for an entire ecosystem of formats that simply can't exist with another business model. Customizable games ultimately need to be lifestyle games, not necessarily for ALL players (the best ones also have some degree of casual accessibility), but at least for some. Those players who invest the most are the ones a game like this depends on, not just in terms of revenue, but also in terms of cultivating a dedicated, passionate community. The time and effort investment of building decks and keeping a local scene churning is substantial, and the players who are willing to engage that for a more restrictive board-game-plus-expansions model are few and far between. Sure, Summoner Wars is fantastic, and you can even build your own decks, but the time and effort needed just to find other players willing to do the same will already turn away many of the players who would otherwise love to engage with the game on that level. And those who stick around aren't as likely to do so, not because the game is worse (it really isn't), but because something like Summoner Wars offers much less variety and much less shakeup in its card pool by virtue of not releasing a handful of 300+ card sets every year.

Turning a card game into a lifestyle game is also much more attainable when players can push back burnout by playing a variety of modes with the same product. Being able to draft one week, then plug the cards you pulled into your standard deck the next week, then tweak your commander deck the next softens the blow of your investment dramatically. Magic: The Gathering's dominance is not just a matter of its game or card design (though it's still better than a number of its competitors in those regards), but in the versatility of its systems. It's not just a lifestyle game, it's several lifestyle games. And these games, at least for some players, are entirely extricable--look how many Magic players nowadays don't bother with anything but Commander, a format originally made by fans to play with bigger groups and give new life to their card collections. It's easy to quit playing one game, but are you going to quit playing all of them? Even putting aside sunk costs and a desire to maintain friend groups bound by the game, there are a lot of justifications for holding onto, or jumping back into, Magic that don't exist for other games.

While ultimately, I think most of the best games out there nowadays are board and card games that fit in a single box--or RPGs that spring forth from a single book and a group's shared imagination--there is something to be said for the sprawl and vigor of a trading card game. There are absolutely board games that can achieve some of the appeals of a TCG, but never all at once. So while the business model was once my chief complaint about Magic, these days, it's just the design. There are other card games that I think are fun enough to warrant looking past the booster pack, or even embracing it. Magic is a design which groans under decades of weight. The designers shepherding MTG these days are incredibly talented and constantly putting out interesting cards that make the most of its systems. Yet every time I play Magic, I can't help but wonder if the land system is going to give me an unwinnable nongame. I can't help but get a bit lost at the walls of text on my opponent's cards, forcing me to guess at new keywords the graphic design hasn't done anything to pick out. I can't help but sigh at the thought of guessing what instants even exist in the game now anytime my opponent ends their turn with open resources.

These days, I'm playing Star Wars: Unlimited. That game, while a bit cheaper than the worst of Magic, still has its share of too-expensive pieces of cardboard. But for once in my life, I'm having enough fun with a collectible game to justify the cost.

- The tradeoff between using a creature to attack, or holding it back to handle an opponent's attack is a great one.
- The mix of known information and bluffing (i.e. possibly Instant in hand to counter) is nice.
- The method of rotating ("tapping") cards to indicate they've been used is an elegant one (afaik this game was the one that introduced it).

- You can be completely stalled due to lack of a certain type of Land. Even in modern (2019!) beginner pre-built decks, I still found half of the (2-color deck) games I played suffered from this. Likewise for needing to draw something to counter a Flying creature, etc. Mulligan helps, but a more fundamental fix is needed imo.
- I'm strongly opposed to the idea of pay-to-win games. It's a major balance issue, and just not a lot of fun (i.e. when budget can dominate skill, this is far worse than winning by dumb luck). Fixed decks handle this, but that eliminates the deckbuilding, which is where most of the strategy lies.

Played Commander for the first time. Had a very good time.

I'll jump right into pros and cons for people deciding whether or not it's worth it to dive into this TCG and it's many rules and formats.

Pros:

- you only need one other player and you can play it online for free (Magic Arena online)
- a 1on1 game can be played fairly quickly and as there are so many different card combinations most likely no games are alike
- the more group oriented format EDH or Commander can be played with 4 people and you can buy any of the recent pre constructed commander decks to dive right in. BUT: Beware as Commander is a little more complicated as you have to be aware of more cards effects at once. Even for experienced players it can get pretty messy and confusing at times
- Constant new releases keep the game fresh, even if it comes at a price. If you find the right group to draft new sets with, it is going to be a blast though!
- Drafts are really where this game shines in my opinion and if you got a group of 8 to share a box it comes at an acceptable price. Even more so if you use some of those cards to build another format called cube to draft more in the future. Another cheap alternative might be Pauper.

Cons:

- Its Pay2win. Literally. Sure there is skill involved but if you do not set up rules in your group you might face up against someone with more money and be defeated in no time = boring. However if you keep some of your cards long enough, some might go up substantially in value, so checking out tcgplayer or cardmarket.com might be worth it once in a while.
- The resource system is terribly outdated. Yes I know they are trying to fix the manaflood or manadrain symptome with different new abilites, but let's face it: it is still a mess. If you are playing a 1on1 and either player draws too many lands (thus no playable cards to interact) or too few lands or not in the right colors (thus cannot play his interactive cards) there is no game. Literally. You draw a land. can't do anything. Next player does something with value. Rinse repeat for 4 turns until the "game" is over. Terrible outdated design. What's even worse is: BOTH players have to draw a balanced amount of lands to interactive cards for a game to take place. The chances are 1/6 ?
It's just laughable. We are using a houserule special mixing technique in our group to prevent this nonsense waste of time: shuffle all creatures all lands and all other cards in 3 separate piles. create 8 stacks in front of you by placing first 8 creatures 1 on each pile, then 8 lands one on each pile, then 1 other card on each pile. Rinse repeat. That's it. You still don't know what's coming, but at least you have a greater chance of having a game. Because guess what, that's still not guaranteed.
- Mulligan. If you draw poorly you might as well surrender instantly. At least that's my experience after 1000+ games. 90% of the time, if you have to mulligan (meaning draw again and remove one card, next time if it is still bad, draw again and remove 2 cards etc.) you start hand with one less card because your opening hand was terrible (too high cost cards or not enough right mana lands) its pretty much game because your opponent hast card advantage. This is more true vs skilled players than vs newbies.
- Discard. The Mill mechanic is somewhat fun because it let's you race for alternative win conditions, one player trying to make you empty your draw pile into your discad pile (graveyard) faster than you can bring his total life sum to zero. But discard? For yourself to discard a card and draw a card sure. But force your opponents to discard 2 cards? That's often game in a 1on1. Its a stupid mechanic that removes decisions from a game. You'll end up with no hand cards and are played by the game instead of having any meaningful decision left to yourself. draw the top card and play it (if possible) We've banned discard opponents hand cards more than 1 from our group. A game is good when you have meaningful and interesting choices/decisions. If a game takes those away it is badly designed. It's that simple. This is on par with roll&move where pure dumb luck decides whether you can take part in a game or not. In My eyes: Waste of time.

So now you know it. A little house rules and a little money, a chill group of people to play with and this can be a blast and bring a wide variety of different types of decks. Just look at edhrec to get a glimpse of the many possiblities of how to design a deck. Other than that it can be incredibly frustrating, especially in magic arena online, where those house rules are not implemented and you cannot take back something you clicked because you misread one word in the bazillion lines of text on those 10 cards. I love Magic. I've played it on and off (mostly on) since I first played it in 1995. I started the game playing casually 1 vs. 1 with my Mom, went on to multi-player at our local store, to competitive local tournaments in Extended and Type II (now Standard), then back to casual cubing and Dandan-ing with a friend, and EDH (now Commander) and multi-player of all-sorts with a mixed group (see separate rating for EDH). I play mostly paper and some online, with the latter going in spates now that Arena exists and is affordable for drafting on the occasions where I feel like it.

I hate the economic model of Magic, it is easily the most expensive game in the world to play if you truly love it and want to have the ability to play what you want, or even the format you want (as sealed / draft is my favourite, but cubing isn't quite the same and new product is expensive as heck. That said, it is also one of the most varied and richly rewarding games ever made. No other game has sustained itself for such prolonged periods of play for me, or has weathered as many storms. Yes, I know the pure abstracts have gone on for millennia and likely will continue as such, but those are always the same game from outing to outing. The beauty of Magic and its unending releases is that as things rotate into and out of the game the strategies can evolve and change. The game today is not the same as the game with a different pool of cards 2 years from now.

Strip away all of the annoyances with the economic model and what remains is one of the most deliciously subtle and varied games ever made. The game is both strategic and tactical and is full of subtle timing nuances and tricky decision trees. That all goes double when you play Limited (sealed formats) as you have to effectively build your deck on the fly and also pilot it effectively. My rating does shift, and a lot, based on what version of Magic we're talking about, as Limited (of any sort) is an easy 10 whereas Commander with 4+ players, my least favourite format ranges between 3 to 6 depending on the length of the game and the individual decks. This is for the same reason why I dislike many, much more random games: the choice of who to beat on in free-for-all formats is often arbitrary, so the game as such frequently doesn't matter and politics is all that really dictates the winner. Unfortunately, Commander is by far the most popular way to play Magic these days, so I get to it much less than I otherwise would.

That said, on an overall scale, it's hard to give this anything less than a 10 as it is one of my all-time favourite games and I am always interested in playing several different versions of it and frequently watch videos of my favourite players playing it even when I am not playing.

I will simply close by saying that after 20 years+ of playing Magic I still find it fascinating and still enjoy shuffling up a new deck. I expect I will still enjoy this another 20 years from now. Fantastic design.

Though Dungeons & Dragons is a close contender, it is likely that there was never anything more revolutionary in the history of tabletop gaming than Magic: The Gathering. Using collectible trading cards as game components was the spark of innovation, but there were many other mechanical elements to the gameplay itself that have ensured its longevity. The color pie, tapping, the mana system, the stack, top-down card designs; if you don't know what any of those things mean, I'd be happy to talk your ear off about each of them and explain how influential each has been.

It's often easy for people to conflate high-randomness with low-strategy. After all, games like Bingo are surely both. And at the opposite end of the spectrum, games like Chess are low-randomness and high-strategy. Yet we can't forget about the Pokers of the world, with obvious high-randomness while also being high-strategy enough for the most brilliant players to become multi-millionaires on the backs of their prowess. Magic also inhabits that quadrant, with tales of devastatingly bad luck sitting proudly alongside unstoppable multi-year champions. Hand management and resource management are paramount here. It is much more tense and unforgiving than many other card games. Yet it also embraces its random elements with gusto.

But of course, both at its advent as well as today, Magic had its detractors, and not without cause. Even to play casually with a group of friends can get expensive, to say nothing of trying to compete in high-level tournaments (or, heaven forbid, to be a pure collector). And certainly there is no shortage of games that tried to "fix" any number of perceived issues with Magic. Yet the fact that they essentially had to bill themselves as "Magic, but..." instead of truly innovating on the genre is itself a testament to the solid foundation of Magic's rules.

And from the revenue generated by that initial phenomenon, an empire arose. Every illustrator working today wants a Magic contract, and consequently, the art is unparalleled. Magic is also without a doubt the most well-designed and most-playtested game in modern times. It's a testament to what devoted gamers can do with a limitless budget and full team of creative people.

Over time, I have come to appreciate more and more how much this is not just a game, but a system. Don't like deckbuilding? Play pre-constructed decks. Don't like people copying the best decks? Play booster draft. Don't like spending money to draft? Build a cube. Don't like 1-on-1 duels? Play Commander or Archenemy. Don't like being so serious? Play Un-sets. A relatively simple rule set creates so many different ways to play. So much focus is put into making this game be something for everyone, that it can hardly help but succeed. There is something here for you, and you do yourself a disservice by not playing.

At the same time, know that if you get into magic, you are signing up for a lifestyle game. People don't really play magic AND other board games. I have played Magic off and on from when I was 13 or so until I was 28. I have many lifelong friends and memories because of this game.

Magic is also the most expensive of hobbies. You can, if you are budget conscious, buy prebuilt commander decks and play with friends, but know that you are potentially getting into far more if you have self-control issues. Unlike with board games where there is a hard upper limit on how many nice components you can buy to improve a board game, there exists no such upper limit for how nice of MTG cards you could buy to make your deck either look better or play better, depending on whether you are playing competitively or not. Even just drafting every once in a while can be expensive.

The set and card designs are more interesting and balanced than in the 90s and 00s, and the variety of game formats one can play, really make this a rich experience.

Finally, throw in the fact that going to prerelease events is consistently among my favorite gaming experiences makes Magic my current #1 “board game” of all time.

Beware of course the predatory FOMO marketing practices and temptation to overspend. But there really is no need to go over the top financially; again, there are so many ways to play and probably my favorite (sealed) is the least expensive dollar-wise.
